The winds cool o’er the loosened fragrant mass
Of leaves decayed in heaps, all shapeless now.
Aloft the sun hangs in its brazen dome,
Unloved—a hell its scorching heat,
Life turns not now, from shade or sheltered home
It’s resting mind, or weary anxious feet.
The leaf is stirred with lizard’s hurried bound
At fly, or insect course, or locust’s wing,
The bird sings not its sweet familiar sound
That folded love, in noonday hours in spring.
The plains are bare, and bones are bleached that seem
Like distant tombs, where grass has never grown
The whirlwind’s dust o’erspread light’s molten stream
That falls on earth, bewild’ring mind and bone.
The fagged-out Fagged-out. Exhausted from exertion. horse, and famished bullock's frame
Die in the bog, or water’s edge unknown,
Man’s friends alas, that once ruled him and name
Now perish there, through want, unthanked, alone.
Where rise the tangled roots of fallen tree,

With nature’s frown on its forsaken lot
This hour, when light has homed the sons of toil,

In vain the words ascend, 'tis High Decree

body.p: PHILIP D. LORIMER. Philip D. Lorimer. Philip Durham Lorimer, known as the Bush Poet or Old Phil the Poet, was an itinerant agricultural labourer and poet who travelled extensively across the east coast of Australia from the early 1880s onwards.
